function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The current page is a checkout page with forms for customer and address information and a selection for payment methods. It includes fields for first name, last name, email, country, street address, city, state, and zip code with John Doe's name and email already filled in. There's a selection for payment methods including Invoice, Credit Card, and PayPal. A submit button is present. The page's header offers navigation options for Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series.","new_testing_goal":"Complete the checkout form by filling in the required address information, select a payment method, and submit to evaluate the website's handling of the checkout process. This includes verifying the correct submission response.","explanation":"First, fill in the remaining address details (country, street address, city, state, zip code) using the appropriate send keys interactions. Then, click on a payment method to select it. Finally, click the submit button to complete the checkout process. This sequence allows us to test the form's functionality, from data entry to submission, and assess the website's response.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3s:","keys":"United States"}}

messages.content: Given a web application, you are tasked with assisting in testing its functionality. The emulate_interaction function takes an interaction as input and emulates it on the web application. The return value of the function is the new, filtered HTML source code of the web application. The source code of previous interactions will be omitted from the input to the assistant.
Here are some examples how the 'emulate_interaction' function should be used.
Please test my website: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description": "The start page of a web site with multiple calculators for different purposes. There are buttons to navigate to the differet calculators and a button to switch the language of the web site. The current language is English.", "new_testing_goal": "Test the calculator for calculating the area of a circle in multiple languages.", "explanation": "First navigate to the calculator for the area of a circle. Then input a radius and calculate the area. Switch the language of the web site and repeat the process.", "interaction": {"interaction_type": "click", "element_id": "btn-area-circle"}}

Then switch the language of the web site and repeat the process.", "interaction": {"interaction_type": "send_keys", "element_id": "radius", "keys": "5"}}

messages.content: Please test my website. The goal is to test as many different features as possible to find potential bugs, so make sure to include edge cases. Here is the filtered HTML source code of the web application: 'omitted'.

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The website currently displays a cart overlay on top of the Galaxy product category page. The cart contains two items with a total amount shown. There are options within the cart to increase or decrease the quantity of items, remove items, clear the cart completely, and a checkout button. The cart overlay can be closed as well, allowing access back to the product listings.","new_testing_goal":"Test the removal and addition of items in the cart, the 'clear cart' functionality, and initiate a checkout process to test the cart's and checkout's response and functionality.","explanation":"To test these functionalities, first remove an item from the cart to see how the web application handles item removal and updates the cart total accordingly. Then, add a product back to the cart to test the addition functionality. Use the 'clear cart' button to see if it correctly empties the cart, then attempt to proceed with a checkout process by clicking the checkout button. This sequence will thoroughly assess cart management and checkout initiation on the website.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"click","element_id":":r3l:"}}

messages.name: emulate_interaction
messages.content: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The website consists of a main navigation bar with options for Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series categories. Below the navigation bar, there's a featured Galaxy products section displaying various models like Galaxy S10 5G, S10+, S10, S10e, A2 Core, M30, M20, M10, A80, A70, A60, A30, each with an 'add to cart' button. Additionally, there’s a cart overlay button indicating zero items in the cart, suggesting no items have been added yet or the cart has been cleared.","new_testing_goal":"Test the 'add to cart' functionality for another product to ensure it works consistently across various products and observe how the cart updates. Subsequently, proceed to checkout to test the transition and functionality of the checkout page.","explanation":"Start by adding another product to the cart to test the 'add to cart' functionality consistency. Choose a different product from the one added in the previous interaction. After adding the item to the cart, observe if the cart overlay updates correctly to reflect the added item. Following this, procced to initiate a checkout by clicking on the checkout button to test the checkout process including the transition and the display of the checkout page correctly.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"click","element_id":":r7:"}}

messages.name: emulate_interaction
messages.content: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The webpage is displaying a checkout interface, including a form with fields for customer and address information along with a selection for payment methods. There's a submit button at the bottom. In the background, it seems like there is a cart overlay indicating that no items are currently in the cart, as the cart total is $0.00. This suggests the user has either not added any items to the cart or has cleared it before proceeding to this checkout page.","new_testing_goal":"Test the checkout process with complete and accurate information to assess the website's handling of transactions and form submissions. This involves filling out all the provided fields correctly and choosing a payment method.","explanation":"First, fill the customer information by sending keystrokes to the first name, last name, and email fields. Then, proceed to fill in the address, including the country, street address, city, state, and zip code. After ensuring all fields are correctly entered, select a payment method. Finally, submit the form by clicking on the submit button. This series of interactions will test the robustness and functionality of the website's checkout process.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3p:","keys":"John"}}

messages.name: emulate_interaction
messages.content: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The checkout page is displayed, focusing on the customer information form. The form is partially filled with 'John' entered in the 'First Name' field. Other fields for the customer's last name, email, and address details (country, street address, city, state, zip code) are empty. There are options to choose a payment method (Invoice, Credit Card, PayPal) and a 'Submit' button to complete the process. Additionally, the website header shows navigation options including Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series.","new_testing_goal":"Continue filling out the checkout form by inputting the last name, email, and address information accurately. This includes selecting a payment method and submitting the form to scrutinize the form's validation, the transaction process, and whether successful submission leads to a confirmation page or message.","explanation":"Fill out the customer's last name and email fields first, followed by the address information (country, street address, city, state, zip code). After all the necessary details are filled out, select a payment method from the available options. Finally, submit the form by clicking on the 'Submit' button. This step-by-step approach allows us to examine the website's handling of checkout procedures, form validation, and the overall user experience during a transaction.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3q:","keys":"Doe"}}

messages.name: emulate_interaction
messages.content: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The website's checkout page is displayed, showcasing a form with fields for customer information (first name and last name are already filled with 'John Doe'), and an empty email field. Additionally, there are address details fields (country, street address, city, state, zip code) which are all empty. Users can choose from three payment methods (Invoice, Credit Card, PayPal) and there's a 'Submit' button for the completion of the checkout process. The navigation bar at the top provides options for Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series.","new_testing_goal":"Fill in the checkout form, focusing on the email, address details, and selecting a payment method. Then, submit the form to test the form submission functionality, error handling, and transition to a confirmation page if any.","explanation":"First, send keystrokes to the email field to fill it out. Then, sequentially fill out the address details fields: country, street address, city, state, and zip code. After accurately filling out these fields, select a payment method by clicking on the preferred option. Finally, submit the form by clicking the 'Submit' button. This sequential filling and submission will allow us to test the form's completeness and error handling capabilities and the website's response to submission.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3r:","keys":"john.doe@example.com"}}

Pursue your self-assigned sub-goal or assign a new one: Fill in the checkout form, focusing on the email, address details, and selecting a payment method. Then, submit the form to test the form submission functionality, error handling, and transition to a confirmation page if any..

Start by describing the website supplied by the function call. Give a short general description first then summarize the main elements on the website. Do not use HTML in your description. Then you may formulate a high level sub-goal to the user's instructions, that should be persued with the next couple of interactions. You should formulate a new sub-goal if the current one has been completed or seems to be unattainable. Give an action plan that explains how the goal should be reached. And finally, describe the interaction to emulate.

Only use the click action with clickable elements. The clickable elements have the following ids: :r3o:, :r0:-home, :r0:-galaxy, :r0:-s10, :r0:-m_series, :r0:-a_series, :r1:, :r2:. Only use the send_keys action with writable elements. The writable elements have the following ids: :r3p:, :r3q:, :r3r:, :r3s:, :r3t:, :r3u:, :r3v:, :r40:. Only use the clear action with clearable elements. The clearable elements have the following ids: :r3p:, :r3q:, :r3r:.

functions.name: emulate_interaction
functions.description: Emulates a user interaction with the web application

page_description.description: A short textual description of the state of the web application: What is the current page? What are the main elements on the page? This description should not contain any HTML.

new_testing_goal.description: Assigns a new high level sub-goal that shall be followed in order to complete the users instructions. This goal should take multiple user interactions to complete. The assistant shall try to complete this goal in the next couple of interactions and then assign a new one.

explanation.description: An action plan that explains how the goal should be reached.

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

keys.description: the keys to be sent to the input element

anyOf.description: sends keystrokes to an html element

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

anyOf.description: resets the contents of an html element
